content:
Fourth CBS News Staffer Tests Positive for Coronavirus
Four CBS News staffers have tested positive for the coronavirus and the network is asking as many employees as possible to work from home. In a memo to staff on Friday, CBS News President Susan Zirinsky said that the fourth employee to test positive had worked closely with the other three. “Each of those who have tested positive have provided ...

Nearly 50 employees at Seattle nursing home at center of coronavirus outbreak test positive for the virus
NEARLY 50 employees of a coronavirus-ridden nursing home in Washington state have tested positive for the disease, officials say. More than two dozen coronavirus deaths have been linked to the Life Care Center, and now a total of 47 employees have tested positive, according to TV station KIRO. BREAKING: First coronavirus death reported in New York
In an morning news conference, Gov. Andrew Cuomo reported that an 82-year-old woman died Friday night due to coronavirus. The woman had also been diagnosed with emphysema. She came into a New York hospital for care on March 3. “We had last night a death in a New York City hospital of an 82-year-old woman who had coronavirus. She came into the ...

New York records first coronavirus death as U.S. toll rises to 48
An 82-year-old woman became New York’s first coronavirus fatality, authorities said on Saturday, after President Donald Trump declared a national emergency and the spread of the pandemic shut down much of the daily routine of American life.

Utah's Rudy Gobert, first NBA player with positive coronavirus test, pledges more than $500,000 for arena employees, others
Utah All-Star center Rudy Gobert, the first NBA player to test positive for the coronavirus, has pledged more than $500,000 “to support both the employee relief fund at Vivint Smart Home Arena and COVID-related social services relief in Utah, Oklahoma City and within the French health care system,” the Jazz said in a news release on Saturday.

Utah Jazz center Rudy Gobert is donating $500,000 to support part-time employees from the Utah Jazz’s home arena and COVID-19 relief funds, the Jazz announced Saturday. The donation comes after Gobert was the first player to test positive for coronavirus on Wednesday night, leading the NBA to suspend the remainder of the season.
